Prompt Level: 13-Advanced [SEP] Prompt: A website has invited you to write your opinion on the topic of corporate social responsibility. Read the postings before you begin. Remember the structure you've learned on how to construct an argument. Write 200-250 words. [SEP] Response: It's clear CSR is necessary in daily life. The reason is that corporations and society share the same spaces and resourses always.  While companies are doing business and getting profits they must share the benefits with their staffs.  This way, they are able to perform better by avoiding employees turnovers and high productivity.

When a company shows consumers care and support  local proyects, it means CSR and in this case, the company are rewarded by consumers loyalty.

There are people saying companies don`t haver social respònsabilty,  arguing that the companies are only interested  on prifits increase. They say too, that CSR is nothing more than publicity stunt. I admit a big target for companies are profits, but at the same time the benefit community offering good jobs and benefits to many people. 

It`s the same when some people say that total earnings are inconsiderable related to the huge amounts of money the companies spend on development projects.  If the companies wouldn't have earning, they would disappear and this would have a big bad impact to the community.

Goverments, companies and society need to work together, all parts with social responsability.  juste in this way it is possible to help costumer, people in need and the world.

Prompt Level: 3-Beginner [SEP] Prompt: Write a paragraph about a job your friend has or had in the past. Include the following: the name of the company, when your friend worked there (if you are describing a past job), the job title and responsibilities, and who your friend reported to. If you don‚Äôt know, you can invent this information. Type in the input box. Write 40-70 words. [SEP] Response: 


O ChatGPT disse:
Claro! Aqui está um exemplo de um texto grande em inglês sobre um tema geral (o impacto da tecnologia na sociedade). Se você quiser sobre outro assunto, é só me avisar!

The Impact of Technology on Modern Society

Technology has become an inseparable part of modern life. From smartphones to artificial intelligence, the influence of technological advancements is evident in nearly every aspect of our daily routine. Over the past few decades, society has undergone rapid transformations driven by innovation, and these changes have brought both significant benefits and complex challenges.

One of the most notable impacts of technology is the way it has revolutionized communication. In the past, people relied on letters and landline phones to stay in touch. Today, social media platforms, video calls, and instant messaging apps allow individuals to communicate instantly across the globe. This global connectivity has made the world feel smaller and more interconnected, fostering cross-cultural understanding and collaboration.

In the field of education, technology has opened up new opportunities for learning. Online courses, digital textbooks, and virtual classrooms have made education more accessible than ever before. Students can now learn at their own pace, from virtually anywhere in the world. This has been particularly valuable during the COVID-19 pandemic, where remote learning became a necessity.

Healthcare has also been transformed by technological progress. Modern medical equipment, electronic health records, and telemedicine services have improved the quality of patient care and made medical services more efficient. In addition, advancements in biotechnology and pharmaceuticals have contributed to longer life expectancies and the treatment of previously incurable diseases.

However, the rise of technology is not without its downsides. Concerns about privacy, cybersecurity, and data misuse have become increasingly prominent. With more personal information being stored online, the risk of data breaches and identity theft has grown. Additionally, there are growing fears that automation and artificial intelligence may lead to widespread job displacement, particularly in industries reliant on repetitive tasks.

Moreover, the pervasive use of digital devices has raised questions about mental health and social isolation. While technology connects us digitally, it can sometimes disconnect us from the physical world and the people around us. Excessive screen time and reliance on virtual interactions may contribute to feelings of loneliness and anxiety.

In conclusion, technology continues to shape the way we live, work, and interact. Its positive contributions to society are undeniable, offering greater convenience, efficiency, and connectivity. However, it is essential to address the challenges it poses with thoughtful policies and ethical considerations. By doing so, we can ensure that technological progress benefits everyone and creates a more equitable and sustainable future.

Prompt Level: 3-Beginner [SEP] Prompt: Read the blog post about someone's hometown, then write about a town you know. Type in the input box. Write 30-50 words. [SEP] Response: South Korea’s culture is a rich blend of tradition and modernity, with deep roots in Confucianism and significant influences from globalization. The country is known for its world-famous pop culture, especially K-pop and K-dramas, which have fans all over the world. In addition, Korean cinema has gained international recognition, as exemplified by the success of the Oscar-winning Parasite.

Korean cuisine is characterized by the use of fermented ingredients, such as kimchi, and dishes such as bibimbap and bulgogi. Food plays a central role in social life, often serving as a means of strengthening family bonds.

In the field of fashion and beauty, Korea is a global reference, with the K-beauty movement and its cosmetics industry being extremely popular. Seoul, the capital, is considered one of the most influential cities in terms of style.

The South Korean education system is highly competitive and values ​​academic achievement. This is also reflected in the work environment, which is marked by long working hours and strong dedication.

Prompt Level: 13-Advanced [SEP] Prompt: A website has invited you to write your opinion on the topic of corporate social responsibility. Read the postings before you begin. Remember the structure you've learned on how to construct an argument. Write 200-250 words. [SEP] Response: Do you believe companies have a responsibility to society? Or do you think a company's only responsibility is to its shareholders? We invite you to join this discussion by posting your opinion on corporate social responsibility (CSR). Below are some quotes from recent submissions. We look forward to hearing from you!
For CSR

Companies have a big impact on society. They should help the communities where they operate. After all, those communities are letting them do business there. It's a two-way street. And it's the same with sustainable operations and fair employee benefits. The former secures future possibilities, and the latter ensures high productivity and low turnover.
– lil@213

The reason CSR makes good business sense, the reason it contributes to the bottom line, is because consumers care. Companies with a good CSR record are rewarded by customer loyalty. Consumers are happy, the company performs well and communities around the world benefit.
– Jack@MSU

As an integrated part of society, corporations need to conform to social expectations, and that entails helping the community.
– James.W@efstudent.com

Against CSR

The problem with corporate social responsibility is that corporations don't have social responsibility. Milton Friedman has pointed out that the real responsibility of business is to increase its profits; business is not answerable to society's expectations but to the shareholders'.
– theG8T

It's great that corporations are spending huge sums of money on development projects across the world, but these sums of money are usually still inconsiderable relative to total earnings. In this sense, it's still quite a cheap marketing device to buy a good public image.
– JackD_92

It's the government's job to make and enforce laws and regulations that will benefit the greater public. Corporations will need to conform to these regulations, but by no means should they be put in the driver's seat.
– patty925

Prompt Level: 14-Advanced [SEP] Prompt: Your boss has asked you to write a formal report recommending a training company. You've chosen Skills Pro. Use your notes to write up the report. Type in the input box. Write 150-200 words. [SEP] Response: After reviewing several training providers, I strongly recommend Skills Pro as the most suitable option, despite its higher cost.

While the company’s courses are more expensive compared to others, this investment is justified by their strong track record. Although many participants have noted that the course content can be challenging, completion rates remain high, indicating that learners are well-supported and motivated throughout the program. This suggests a balance between rigor and accessibility that leads to tangible outcomes.

Furthermore, Skills Pro has outlined clear plans to expand and enhance their course offerings. This forward-thinking approach reflects a commitment to continuous improvement and adaptability, ensuring their content remains current and competitive.

In summary, Skills Pro stands out for its course effectiveness, high completion rates, and strategic growth plans. These factors position it as a valuable partner for meeting our team’s professional development goals. I recommend moving forward with them.

I am confident that partnering with Skills Pro will lead to measurable improvements in our team’s capabilities and long-term performance.

Prompt Level: 15-Advanced [SEP] Prompt: Apply the language you've learned in this lesson to a new topic: language learning. Write about issues and challenges that language students often face. Ask yourself guiding questions to help organize the writing. Type in the input box. Write 150-250 words. [SEP] Response: Today, I took a test designed to reflect everything I’ve learned throughout my EF online course. It was a meaningful experience because it gave me the chance to put into practice the knowledge I’ve been building over the past year. The result wasn’t bad—I passed! I got the hand of the reading and grammar sections, which came quite easily to me.

However, I wasn’t entirely satisfied. I faced some challenges, particularly with the writing and speaking portions of the test. I've found it surprisingly difficult to came up with the right words to write and express orally. Next time, one thing I need to do is to focus more on internalizing key vocabulary and different ways of expressing ideas. Also, I don't know if it's going to be efficient, but next time I might thought about using ChatGPT to support my preparation. If I provide the AI with the content from the EF platform and craft the right prompts, I believe I could practice the speaking component more effectively.

Prompt Level: 16-Upper Advanced [SEP] Prompt: Write a description of a legendary creature that‚Äôs popular in your country, or one you find interesting. Type in the input box. Write 150-200 words. [SEP] Response: The Garuda is a legendary creature deeply rooted in Indian mythology and is revered as a divine being in Hinduism. Described as a colossal, eagle-like bird with the body of a man, Garuda is the mount (vahana) of Lord Vishnu, one of the principal deities in Hinduism. Often depicted with a golden, radiant body, mighty wings, and an imposing beak, Garuda symbolizes power, speed, and martial prowess.

In various texts, Garuda is portrayed as a sworn enemy of serpents, embodying the eternal struggle between good and evil. This enmity is often attributed to his mission to free his mother from servitude by obtaining the nectar of immortality. Garuda's birth is itself a tale of divine intervention—hatched from a massive egg laid by his mother, Vinata, after a prolonged and arduous penance.

Garuda's imagery is prevalent in Indian art and architecture, often seen adorning temples and sacred sites as a guardian figure. Beyond Hinduism, Garuda holds significance in Buddhist and Jain traditions, embodying virtues such as loyalty and bravery. His legacy transcends religious boundaries, making Garuda an enduring symbol of divine intervention and moral righteousness in Indian culture.

Prompt Level: 15-Advanced [SEP] Prompt: Apply the language you've learned in this lesson to a new topic: language learning. Write about issues and challenges that language students often face. Ask yourself guiding questions to help organize the writing. Type in the input box. Write 150-250 words. [SEP] Response: Language learning presents various challenges that can hinder progress for many students. One significant issue is the fear of speaking, which often stems from anxiety about making mistakes. How can learners overcome this fear? Creating a supportive environment where mistakes are viewed as learning opportunities can encourage more practice and confidence in speaking.
Another common challenge is the difficulty in retaining vocabulary and grammar rules. What strategies can help with memorization? Techniques such as spaced repetition, flashcards, and contextual learning can enhance retention and make the learning process more effective.
Additionally, many students struggle with finding the right resources and methods that suit their learning style. How can learners identify the best tools for their needs? Experimenting with various resources—such as language apps, online courses, and conversation groups—can help students discover what works best for them.
Lastly, maintaining motivation over time can be a hurdle. What can students do to stay engaged? Setting clear, achievable goals and regularly assessing progress can help sustain motivation and provide a sense of accomplishment.

Prompt Level: 13-Advanced [SEP] Prompt: You are writing to Harry, a new manager in your company. He wants advice on how to effectively motivate his team and what strategies to avoid. Use the language and strategies you have learned in this lesson. Type in the input box. Write 150-200 words. [SEP] Response: 


---

Harry,

Welcome aboard! Motivating a team effectively is essential for long-term success. Here are some key strategies that can help you lead with confidence.

First, build trust by being transparent and approachable. When employees feel heard and respected, they’re more likely to stay engaged. Set clear expectations and provide regular, constructive feedback. Recognize achievements both big and small — this shows your team their efforts are valued.

Offer opportunities for growth, such as training or mentorship programs. People are more motivated when they see a future within the company. Also, promote a healthy work-life balance; a burned-out team is an unproductive one.

Now, some strategies to avoid: never take credit for your team's work — always give credit where it’s due. Avoid micromanaging, as it kills creativity and confidence. Don’t ignore problems or complaints; doing so can lead to resentment. And finally, never let disrespect or unfair treatment go unaddressed.

With empathy, fairness, and strong communication, you’ll create a team that feels inspired and supported.

Best of luck!



---

In conclusion, companies should not operate in isolation from the society they benefit from. Social responsibility isn’t just good ethics—it’s good business. The world today needs organizations that care not only about what they produce but also about the impact they leave behind.

Students face several common obstacles that can slow their progress or even discourage them. One major challenge is *lack of confidence*. Many learners fear making mistakes, which prevents them from practicing speaking and writing. However, mistakes are a natural part of learning and should be embraced as opportunities to improve.

Another difficulty is *limited exposure to the target language*. Students who do not regularly listen to native speakers or engage in conversations struggle to develop fluency. Immersion—through music, movies, and conversations—can help reinforce vocabulary and pronunciation.

Grammar complexity can also be intimidating. Many languages have intricate rules that learners find confusing. Instead of memorizing endless rules, students can benefit from understanding patterns and practicing in real-life situations.

Finally, *motivation and consistency* are crucial. Learning a language requires patience, and it is easy to lose motivation if progress feels slow. Setting achievable goals, using engaging resources, and celebrating small victories can keep students motivated.

Prompt Level: 16-Upper Advanced [SEP] Prompt: Write a description of a legendary creature that‚Äôs popular in your country, or one you find interesting. Type in the input box. Write 150-200 words. [SEP] Response: One of the most legendary creatures popular in Indian mythology is the Nāga. Nāgas are serpentine beings that are revered and feared across various Indian cultural and religious traditions, particularly in Hinduism, Buddhism, and Jainism. They are often depicted as half-human and half-cobra, possessing a human upper body and the lower body of a serpent.

Nāgas are considered to be powerful and possess a range of supernatural abilities. They are believed to reside in the underworld, known as Nāga-loka, which is a vast realm filled with treasures. They are also associated with bodies of water such as rivers, lakes, and seas, and are said to have control over rain and fertility.

In Hindu mythology, Nāgas are sometimes seen as protectors and are worshipped as water deities. They are known to guard treasures and are sometimes associated with hidden wisdom and esoteric knowledge. Ananta, also known as Shesha, is a prominent Nāga who serves as the bed upon which Lord Vishnu rests. Another well-known Nāga is Vasuki, who played a significant role in the churning of the ocean (Samudra Manthan) to obtain the nectar of immortality.

Nāgas can also be malevolent, known to bring disasters or misfortune to those who disrespect them or encroach upon their domains. As such, they are both revered and appeased through various rituals and offerings.

In Buddhist traditions, Nāgas are considered protectors of the Buddha and the Dharma. They are often depicted in Buddhist art and literature as beings who paid homage to the Buddha and were converted to his teachings.

Overall, Nāgas are complex beings embodying dual aspects of benevolence and danger, deeply woven into the rich tapestry of Indian mythology and culture.

Prompt Level: 15-Advanced [SEP] Prompt: Apply the language you've learned in this lesson to a new topic: language learning. Write about issues and challenges that language students often face. Ask yourself guiding questions to help organize the writing. Type in the input box. Write 150-250 words. [SEP] Response: Language learning can be a rewarding yet challenging process. Many students face obstacles that hinder their progress, making the journey feel overwhelming at times. One common issue is **motivation**. Learning a new language requires consistent practice and effort, and without clear goals or reasons for learning, it's easy to lose enthusiasm.

Another challenge is **vocabulary retention**. Language students often struggle to remember and effectively use new words. It can be frustrating when you learn a word but forget it the next day, which slows down overall fluency. Additionally, **grammar** presents difficulties for many learners. Each language has its own set of rules and structures, and mastering these can be confusing, especially when they differ significantly from one's native tongue.

Pronunciation and **accent** are also frequent concerns. In languages with sounds that don’t exist in the learner's first language, producing these sounds correctly can feel nearly impossible.

Finally, **cultural differences** can be another obstacle. Understanding the culture behind a language is key to truly mastering it, but this often requires exposure to the language in real-world contexts, which is not always feasible.

Despite these challenges, language learning can be a rewarding experience with the right mindset, patience, and strategies.

Prompt Level: 15-Advanced [SEP] Prompt: Apply the language you've learned in this lesson to a new topic: language learning. Write about issues and challenges that language students often face. Ask yourself guiding questions to help organize the writing. Type in the input box. Write 150-250 words. [SEP] Response: Learning a new language is a rewarding yet challenging endeavor. Many students face various obstacles during their language-learning journey. One common challenge is motivation. Maintaining consistent effort can be difficult, especially when progress feels slow or when students feel overwhelmed by the complexity of grammar and vocabulary. To combat this, it’s essential to set small, achievable goals and celebrate milestones along the way.

Another issue is lack of practice opportunities. While students can learn grammar rules and vocabulary, applying them in real conversations is crucial for fluency. In areas where the language isn’t widely spoken, finding people to converse with can be a struggle. Language exchange platforms, language meetups, or speaking with native speakers online can provide valuable practice.

Additionally, pronunciation and accent often pose difficulties. It can be intimidating for students to speak out loud, especially when they feel their accent is not quite right. Overcoming this fear requires building confidence through consistent practice and seeking constructive feedback.

Finally, language interference—where the student's first language affects how they learn or use the new language—can cause confusion. For instance, sentence structure or false cognates can lead to mistakes. To address this, students should immerse themselves in the language and practice regularly, as repetition helps solidify correct patterns.

By recognizing and addressing these challenges, students can improve their language skills more effectively.

Prompt Level: 12-Upper Intermediate [SEP] Prompt: You're going to reply to Alice's blog post about cross-cultural communication. Give advice about your own culture. Type in the input box. Write 50-75 words. Use your own words where possible. [SEP] Response: The Journey of a Dreamer

It was a bright and chilly morning when Jack stood by the window, gazing out at the sprawling city. The world seemed so vast and full of opportunities, yet he couldn't shake off the feeling that something was missing. For years, he had followed the path laid out for him: finish school, get a stable job, and live a comfortable life. But inside, Jack always felt like there was more to life than just playing it safe.

Every day, he passed by the same familiar streets, and yet he couldn't help but wonder what lay beyond them. He had dreams—big dreams—but they always seemed out of reach. His heart longed for adventure, for the kind of freedom that comes with stepping into the unknown. Jack knew he had to make a choice: continue living a life of routine or take a leap of faith and pursue the dream that had always burned within him.

One afternoon, Jack made the decision. He packed his things, said goodbye to his old job, and boarded a flight to a faraway land. It wasn’t the easiest decision he had ever made. There were doubts, fears, and endless what-ifs running through his mind. But deep down, he knew that this was the only way to truly live.

His first stop was a small coastal village in Portugal. The moment Jack arrived, the scent of the sea and the sound of crashing waves immediately put him at ease. He felt like he was in the right place. In the city, he had been just another face in the crowd, but here, he was a stranger in a new world, and that felt both humbling and exciting.

Jack spent his days exploring the narrow, cobblestone streets, meeting new people, and learning about the culture. He discovered that life in the village was simple but beautiful. The locals were warm and welcoming, always eager to share their stories. Every evening, Jack would sit at a local café, sipping coffee as the sun dipped below the horizon, casting a golden glow over the sea. It was in these moments that he felt alive, truly alive in a way he hadn’t in years.

As the weeks passed, Jack began to understand something important: his dreams were not about grand accomplishments or fame. They were about living authentically, experiencing life without the constraints of fear or societal expectations. In the village, he found not only peace but also clarity.

One evening, as Jack walked along the beach, he met an old fisherman named Miguel. The man had a weathered face and hands rough from years of work, but his eyes were kind and full of wisdom. They struck up a conversation, and soon, Jack found himself listening to Miguel’s life story. The fisherman had spent most of his years out on the sea, learning the ways of the ocean, the winds, and the tides. But it wasn’t just the sea that taught Miguel lessons. It was the quiet moments, the long hours of solitude, and the simplicity of life that had given him the most valuable lessons.

"Sometimes," Miguel said, "we think that we have to follow a certain path. We believe that the future is something we can control. But in reality, life has a way of guiding us where we need to go, even when we don’t know it ourselves."

Jack thought about this for a long time. It wasn’t about having everything figured out. It was about trusting the journey and embracing the unknown. Over the next few months, Jack learned to let go of the need for control. He stopped worrying about what he should be doing or where he was supposed to be. Instead, he followed his heart, trusting that the right opportunities would come at the right time.

By the time Jack returned to the city, he was a changed man. He no longer felt the pressure to live up to other people’s expectations. He had realized that the greatest adventure of all was the journey of self-discovery. Jack began to pursue his passions—photography, writing, and traveling—and soon found that the world had more to offer than he had ever imagined.

In the end, Jack’s journey wasn’t just about the places he visited or the people he met. It was about the person he became along the way. He had learned to embrace uncertainty, to trust in the beauty of the unknown, and to live with purpose. And that, he realized, was the greatest dream of all.

Remember the structure you've learned on how to construct an argument. Write 200-250 words. [SEP] Response: My Opinion on Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR)

I strongly believe that companies do have a responsibility towards society. While it is true that businesses exist to make profits, ignoring their social impact can lead to long-term negative consequences for both the community and the company itself.

First of all, companies operate within communities that provide them with workers, customers, and infrastructure. It is only fair that they give something back. Initiatives like offering fair wages, investing in environmental sustainability, and supporting local development are ways to build trust and long-term success.

Moreover, CSR makes good business sense. As Jack@MSU pointed out, customers today care about social and environmental issues. Companies with a strong CSR image often enjoy higher customer loyalty and positive brand reputation. This can directly impact their financial performance.

On the other hand, I understand the argument that a company’s main goal is profit and that the government should enforce social welfare policies. However, I believe CSR is not about replacing government responsibilities but complementing them. Companies have the resources and influence to make a difference.

In conclusion, companies should go beyond simply maximizing profits. By adopting CSR practices, they not only help society but also create a sustainable environment for their own growth.

A final burst of crimson red,
Before the sun lies down its head.

The sky, the earth, the moon, the hill.

Cradled by the quiet love
Of twilight's endless, tender grace,

Prompt Level: 13-Advanced [SEP] Prompt: You are writing to Harry, a new manager in your company. He wants advice on how to effectively motivate his team and what strategies to avoid. Use the language and strategies you have learned in this lesson. Type in the input box. Write 150-200 words. [SEP] Response:  Motivating your team is essential for creating a positive, productive, and engaging work environment. When your team feels motivated, they are more likely to perform at their best, stay committed, and contribute to the overall success of your organization. Here are some friendly and practical tips to help you motivate your team effectively:

Encourage Open Communication
Create an environment where team members feel comfortable sharing their ideas, concerns, and feedback. Listen actively and show genuine interest in what they have to say. This builds trust and makes them feel valued.

Recognize and Celebrate Achievements
Acknowledge individual and team accomplishments regularly. Simple gestures like saying “good job” or giving small rewards can boost morale and motivate everyone to keep striving for excellence.

Set Clear Goals and Expectations
Help your team understand what is expected of them. Clear goals give direction and purpose, making it easier for team members to stay focused and motivated.

Provide Opportunities for Growth
Offer training, workshops, or new responsibilities that allow team members to develop their skills. When people see opportunities for personal and professional growth, they tend to be more engaged.

Foster a Positive Work Environment
Create a space where positivity, respect, and collaboration thrive. Encourage teamwork and support among colleagues. A friendly atmosphere makes work more enjoyable.

Offer Autonomy and Trust
Allow team members to take ownership of their tasks. Trusting them to make decisions shows confidence in their abilities and motivates them to perform well.

Be Supportive and Approachable
Show empathy and be available to help when needed. When team members know they can rely on you, they feel more secure and motivated.

Provide Constructive Feedback
Offer feedback that is specific, helpful, and encouraging. Focus on solutions and improvements rather than just pointing out mistakes.

Create a Sense of Purpose
Help your team see how their work contributes to larger goals or the company's mission. Feeling that their work makes a difference can be highly motivating.

Encourage Work-Life Balance
Respect personal time and promote a healthy balance between work and personal life. Happy, rested employees are more productive and motivated.

Maintain Fairness and Transparency
Be honest and fair in your dealings. Transparency about decisions and processes builds trust and loyalty.

Lead by Example
Demonstrate enthusiasm, dedication, and a positive attitude. Your behavior sets the tone for the team.

Create Opportunities for Social Interaction
Organize team-building activities or informal gatherings. Building strong relationships fosters a sense of belonging and motivation.

Set Realistic and Achievable Goals
Avoid setting unattainable targets. Achievable goals help maintain motivation and prevent frustration.

Encourage Innovation and Creativity
Allow team members to suggest new ideas and approaches. Feeling that their input matters motivates them to be more engaged.

Provide Adequate Resources and Support
Ensure your team has the tools and support needed to do their jobs effectively. Frustration from lack of resources can diminish motivation.

Celebrate Milestones and Successes
Mark important achievements with celebrations or acknowledgments. Recognizing progress keeps momentum going.

Be Patient and Understanding
Everyone has good days and bad days. Show patience and understanding, especially during challenging times.

Maintain a Friendly and Respectful Attitude
Treat everyone with kindness and respect. A friendly environment encourages motivation and loyalty.

Avoid Negative Behaviors
Refrain from disrespect, blaming others, or losing your temper. Negative attitudes can demotivate and create a toxic environment.

Encourage Collaboration
Promote teamwork and collective problem-solving. Working together can inspire new.

How do learners stay engaged when progress feels slow? One solution is to set small, realistic goals. Celebrating small victories—like learning 10 new words or understanding a short video—can keep motivation high. Prompt Level: 13-Advanced [SEP] Prompt: A website has invited you to write your opinion on the topic of corporate social responsibility. Read the postings before you begin. Remember the structure you've learned on how to construct an argument. Write 200-250 words. [SEP] Response: My Opinion on Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR)
 
I believe companies do have a responsibility to society, beyond just generating profits for their shareholders. While it is true that a company must be financially successful to survive, long-term success increasingly depends on how businesses interact with the communities and environments they operate in.
 
First, consumers today are more aware and socially conscious. They often choose to support companies that demonstrate ethical behavior, care for the environment, and treat their workers fairly. This is not only a moral argument but also a practical one: good CSR builds trust, strengthens brand reputation, and encourages customer loyalty. For example, a company that invests in sustainable practices or community education programs is more likely to be viewed positively, which ultimately contributes to its profitability.
 
Secondly, corporations are a part of society and benefit from the infrastructure, labor force, and natural resources provided by it. Giving back is not just charity—it’s about maintaining the ecosystem that supports their existence. Neglecting social responsibilities may lead to public backlash, government intervention, or even employee dissatisfaction.
 
Of course, CSR should not replace government action, but it can complement it. When businesses and governments work together, they can address societal challenges more effectively.
 
In conclusion, corporate social responsibility is not a burden but an opportunity—for ethical growth, brand loyalty, and long-term stability.
